issue.title: DNS support for a DNS resolver other than Akka's default

milestone.title: 1.0.0-RC1
milestone.description: Stable APIs, several breaking changes since 0.20

repository.name: akka-management
repository.description: Akka Management is a suite of tools for operating Akka Clusters.

issue.body:
Currently it is required to override `akka.io.dns.resolver` to use `async-dns` to use SRV records.
However `async-dns` does't support features such as looking at `/etc/hosts` and search domains: https://github.com/akka/akka/issues/25825

Meaning other Akka components e.g. HTTP/TCP may stop working if they rely on these features.

Similar to how bootstrap can override the service discovery mechanism, DNS service discovery should be able to use its own dns resolver.

rename.from: Support DNS search list in the async DNS provider
rename.to: Support DNS search list suffixes in the async DNS provider

rename.from: Support DNS search list suffixes in the async DNS provider
rename.to: Support DNS search domains in the async DNS provider

body:
The search domains on Linux end up in /etc/resolve.conf

For example in Kubernetes this is populated in a container with something like:

```
search akka-bootstrap.svc.cluster.local svc.cluster.local cluster.local
```

Where `akka-bootstrap` is the namespace the pod is running in.

This feature is pretty important to run on Kubernetes. Without it, you need to have a different discovery configuration for every different namespace that you might deploy a service to, for example, this makes the configuration a lot more complex when having different namespaces for test, staging and production environments.

issue.title: Async DNS search domain support

labels.name: tested
labels.description: PR that was successfully built and tested by Jenkins

repository.name: akka-core
repository.description: A platform to build and run apps that are elastic, agile, and resilient. SDK, libraries, and hosted environments.

issue.body:
Fixes #25825

Provides search domain support for Async DNS.

There are two parts here, first is the search domain support itself, which is relatively straight forward - on lookup, create a list of hosts to attempt to resolve based on the search domains configuration (including the host with no postfix), exclude all those hosts that have less dots than the configured ndots, and then search until you find one that returns any records. In this case the search domains are applied for each nameserver attempt, so if a particular nameserver times out, it won't attempt to search any more domains on that nameserver.

The second part is in actually detecting the system configuration. I've only implemented partial support here, it reads /etc/resolv.conf, and nothing else. There are ways to detect it on other platforms, there are also environment variables that are supposed to be honored on Linux and other *nix's, but to keep this change manageable, I've focussed on just supporting the minimum to meet the Kubernetes service discovery use case, and documented the limitations.

issue.title: Implemented per service mapping
issue.body:
Fixes #24

This implements per service mapping of service name, port, protocol and scheme.

The `ServiceNameParser` has been renamed to `ServiceNameMapper`, because that's now what it essentially does, maps a Lagom service name to an Akka discover lookup, plus scheme. It first attempts to do the mapping via direct configuration. If there's no mapping there, it then attempts to do the mapping parsing it using the regex, and if that yields no mapping, then it just uses the service name as is with the configured default port, protocol and mapped scheme.
